The top point charge has a charge of <math alttext="positive 3 Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>Q</mi></math>, and each of the point charges located on the base of the triangle has a charge of <math alttext="negative 2 Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>Q</mi></math>. Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math> is located at the midpoint of the base of the triangle, as shown. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(a) Derive an expression for the work required to assemble the charges in the configuration shown.
(b) Derive an expression for the magnitude of the electric field at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>.
(c) On the following charge configuration, draw a Gaussian surface that would have the maximum amount of net electric flux enter or exit its surface.
(d) Derive an expression for the electric potential at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>.

(e) A positive test charge <math alttext="lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math> is placed at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>.

i. On the following diagram, draw an arrow to indicate the direction of the net force exerted on the test charge. The arrow should start on, and point away from, the dot.

ii. The locations of the point charges at the top and bottom right corner of the triangle are switched, as shown in the following diagram.

Does the direction of the net force on the test charge change? If the direction changes, indicate the direction of the new net force, and justify your answer. If the direction does not change, justify your answer.

(f) The charges are returned to their initial positions. 

i. On the following diagram, put an “<math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>x</mtext></math>” at a location where an additional negative charge could be placed so the net force on the <math alttext="positive 3 Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>Q</mi></math> charge would be zero.
ii. Explain your reasoning for the location indicated in part (f)(i).
